Authors:
E. W. A. Boehm, Guy Marson, Geir Harald Mathiassen , Alain
Gardiennet, Conrad L Schoch
Title: A phylogenetic placement for the genus Glyphium
Abstract:
The genus Glyphium Nitschke ex Lehmann is characterized by
erect, carbonaceous ligulate to dolabrate ascomata, which are strongly
laterally compressed, and dehisce along a longitudinal slit, running
parallel to the compressed axis of the fruitbody. The five currently
recognized species are separated primarily by whether the ascospores
disassociate into part-spores within the ascus. Non-disarticulating
species include the cosmopolitan Glyphium elatum (Grev.) Zogg,
designated as type, and G. tillandsiae (Cash) Zogg, collected only from
Florida. Species with disarticulating ascospores include G. corrugatum
(Ellis) Goree, from the Western United States and Canada, and the two
morphologically related European species, G. grisonense Math., and G.
schizosporum (Maire) H. Zogg. The genus has traditionally been
classified in the Mytilinidiaceae Kirschst. (Mytilinidiales,
Pleosporomycetidae, Dothideomycetes). The present study, based on fresh
material representing European specimens of G. elatum and G. grisonense,
was initiated to determine the correct phylogenetic placement of the
genus Glyphium. Sequence alignments of the LSU, SSU, TEF1 and RPB2,
derived from six accessions, four from type species, G. elatum, and two
from G. grisonense, clearly indicate that the genus Glyphium belongs
within the Pleosporomycetidae, within the Dothideomycetes, and most
surprisingly shows close affinities with Patellaria and Hysteropatella,
in the Patellariales.
